user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, OS_SocketDomain_t Domain)
{
    sa_family_t             sa_family;
    socklen_t               addrlen;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    memset(Addr, 0, sizeof(OS_SockAddr_t));
    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Domain)
    {
        case OS_SocketDomain_INET:
            sa_family = AF_INET;
            addrlen   = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case OS_SocketDomain_INET6:
            sa_family = AF_INET6;
            addrlen   = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            sa_family = 0;
            addrlen   = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (addrlen == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    }

    Addr->ActualLength     = OSAL_SIZE_C(addrlen);
    Accessor->sa.sa_family = sa_family;

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketDomain_INVALID, /**< @brief Invalid */
    OS_SocketDomain_INET,    /**< @brief IPv4 address family, most commonly used) */
    OS_SocketDomain_INET6,   /**< @brief IPv6 address family, depends on OS/network stack support */
    OS_SocketDomain_MAX      /**< @brief Maximum */
} OS_SocketDomain_t
...
#define OSAL_SIZE_C(X) ((size_t)(X))
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in the provided function appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Reasoning:
- The function parameter Addr is written to (memset(Addr, ...); Addr->ActualLength = ...), so it must be a pointer to a non-const object; making it a pointer-to-const would be incorrect.
- The Accessor pointer is assigned from &Addr->AddrData and is used to modify Accessor->sa.sa_family; it therefore must refer to a mutable object and cannot be const-qualified.
- There are no other pointer variables in the function that are only read; all pointer usage in this function involves modification of the pointed-to object (or passing to memset which expects a void*). Thus there are no places where a pointer could be changed to point to a const-qualified type without altering intended behavior.
- The cast (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData is a type conversion but does not imply that the resulting pointer should be const; it is used to write into the address storage.
Given the observable code and its use of the pointers to perform modifications, there are no suspicious fragments to investigate under Rule 8.13.
